Deliberate-Practice (7/66)
The contents of this chapter were revolved around two fundamental questions:

html:li.html:em: How do we make sure a program doesn't do what we don't want it to do?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the first question, we introduce two modes user mode and kernel mode. In user mode, we are restricted with what sort of operations we can run.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: More importantly, in user mode, we are limited with what we can see. We will see later on in memory, but in user mode we have a limited address space allocated for the current process. However, in kernel mode, the address space is the entire computer and can therefore be very dangerous if we are not careful.
How do we switch from user and kernel mode without allowing processes to run instructions in kernel mode?
We must have some cooperation from the hardware. Namely, on boot, the OS code is run and sets up a trap table.

The hardware has some responsibility when switching to kernel mode. Namely, it must store two types of registers (1) user registers (2) kernel register.
The user registers are registers that contain the current program context i.e. stack variables, such as x = 1.
The kernel registers hold more meta-information, such as the PC, the syscall number of the calling syscall, etc.
Kellen Kanarios2025719Remark Each time we return to a process or switch between processes the hardware must perform a context switch. This is when they store all of the context of the current program before replacing it with the context of another program. The cost of such a switch is the tradeoff when performing scheduling of processes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In order to implement the syscall, there needs to be some pre-agreed upon arrangement on where certain things go. For example, the syscall number must be stored in a pre-defined register. The general procedure (I think?) is as follows:

html:ol.html:li: syscall calls trap instruction defined by hardware.
hardware stores all information necessary to restore processes in pre-determined location.
hardware switches to kernel mode from user mode.
hardware jumps to code in OS to handle syscall (trap handler / interrupt handler?).
OS code checks pre-arranged register for the syscall number
OS executes corresponding syscall code.
OS restores program.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Due to relying on pre-determined registers, the syscalls are typically hand coded in assembly.
The OS must also perform checks regarding the safety of the requested operation i.e. we cannot let a process read the kernel code...
There is a similar mechanism for interrupts via an interrupt handler.
If the CPU is running a process, then how can the kernel decide to stop running it?
It can't... Instead the hardware performs period interrupts that trap to the OS code. The OS code can then decide what process to run via the scheduler (next section).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This section is a summary of my findings:

html:ol.html:li: Power signals reset of CPU state.
CPU runs BIOS, which checks that hardware works.
BIOS then runs bootloader (i.e. grub).
Bootloader places kernel code in right place and runs it.
Kernel then specifies things like trap table location (which is a special hardware instruction). Also must set timer.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate practice (5/66).

Pre-norm vs. Post-norm: The first architecture variation discussed is when to apply the layer norm. As can be seen in the figure below, rather than apply the layer norm in the residual stream. They instead place it before the FFN and MHA layers.
They actually found that adding layer normalization before and after the MHA and FFN works the best. This is known as double norm.
RMSNorm vs. LayerNorm: Another useful trick is to use the RMSNorm instead of LayerNorm.

The RMS norm is simply the layer norm without the added bias term and centering i.e. \mathrm {RMSNorm}: \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R}^d, \quad \mathbf {x} \mapsto \frac {\mathbf {x}}{\sqrt {\mathrm {Var}[\mathbf {x}_i] + \epsilon }}*\gamma . This is used to spare memory movement of layernorm, where the bias term \beta \in \mathbb {R}^d and has been found to be empirically almost if not as good.
One might wonder if matrix multiplies are the only thing that matters what can such a small change really accomplish.

html:ul.html:li: Due to memory movement, despite being .17% of FLOPS, provided 25% speedup in runtime!!

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Most people apparently just drop the bias term and keep the centering i.e. subtracting the mean. This makes sense because computing the mean does not require loading any additional information back to memory.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Despite a long list of activations, the two focused on are ReLU and GELU.

The rectified linear unit(ReLU) is defined as \mathrm {ReLU} : \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R}^d, \quad \mathbf {x} \mapsto \max (0, \mathbf {x}), where the \max is done elementwise i.e. \mathrm {ReLU}(\mathbf {x})_i = \max (0, x_i) This provides "nice" gradients, making it common when training neural networks.

The Gaussian Error Linear Unit (GELU) is a slight modification to the ReLU to account for the non-differentiability at 0. Namely, \mathrm {GELU}(\mathbf {x}) : \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R}^d, \quad \mathbf {x} \mapsto \mathbf {x} \cdot \psi (\mathbf {x}), where \psi (\mathbf {x}) = \mathrm {CDF}(\mathcal {N}(\mathbf {x}, \mathbf {I}))

html:figure.html:figcaption: GELU vs. ReLU activation and derivative. Taken from here.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Swish activation is given by \mathrm {Swish}(\mathbf {x}) : \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R}^d, \quad \mathbf {x} \mapsto \mathbf {x} s(\mathbf {x}), where s : \mathbb {R}^d \to \mathbb {R}^d is the sigmoid function.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The extra computation required by GELU or Swish is a non-factor because FLOPS are dominated by matrix multiplication and there is no increase in memory pressure.

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
A gated linear unit is an activation function combined with an elementwise multiplication i.e.
\mathrm {ReGLU} = \mathrm {ReLU}(\mathbf {x}) \otimes \mathbf {V} \mathbf {x},
\mathrm {SwiGLU} = \mathrm {Swish}(\mathbf {x}) \otimes \mathbf {V} \mathbf {x}, where \mathrm {ReLU} is the ReLU activation and \mathrm {Swish} is the Swish activation respectively.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The matrix \mathbf {V} introduces additional learnable parameters. Therefore, an architecture that uses gating typically reduces their other parameters by a factor of \frac {2}{3}.

Another small trick is to parallelize computation. Traditionally, one computes the \mathrm {MHA} output and then passes this to the \mathrm {FFN} i.e. \mathbf {y} = \mathbf {x} + \mathrm {FFN}(\mathrm {LN}(\mathbf {x} + \mathrm {MHA}(\mathrm {LN}(\mathbf {x})))). However, this requires waiting for the \mathrm {MHA} to complete before performing the \mathrm {FFN} computation. It has been found that performing these in parallel does not cause any severe degradation in performance. Explicitly, instead they do \mathbf {y} = \mathbf {x} + \mathrm {FFN}(\mathrm {LN}(\mathbf {x})) + \mathrm {MHA}(\mathrm {LN}(\mathbf {x}))

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Notation: For this section, our notion of an embedding is a function f that takes a token and a position i.e. f(x, i) is the embedding of token x, occurring at position i.

Idea: the inner product of two embeddings should only need relative positioning i.e. for any two \mathbf {x}, \mathbf {y} with positions i and j respectively, there should exist some g, such that \langle f(\mathbf {x}, i), f(\mathbf {y}, j) \rangle = g(\mathbf {x}, \mathbf {y}, i - j) Namely, this can be written as a function of just the relative positioning between the embeddings.
The simplest transformation that only preserves this relative information are rotations.

html:figure.html:figcaption: Rotating embeddings does not change relative position.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: However, rotations are only easily defined for \mathbb {R}^2. To get around this, they simply partition their input 2d slices and apply the rotation via \mathrm {ROT} = \begin {bmatrix} \cos m \theta _{1} & - \sin m \theta _{1} & & & \\ \sin m \theta _{1} & \cos m \theta _{1} & & & \\ & & \cos m \theta _{2} & -\sin m \theta _{2} & \\ & & \sin m \theta _{2} & \cos m \theta _{2} & \\ & & & & \ddots \end {bmatrix}

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The \theta _i's are fixed and chosen according to some schedule to capture different "frequencies".

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The embedding are used by appling them to the query and key matrices separately i.e. W_K = \mathrm {ROT}(W_K), \quad W_Q = \mathrm {ROT}(W_Q) These are then what is used in self-attention.
Exception 1: in the case of GLUs, we recall that to account for extra parameters we scale \frac {2}{3}. Therefore, d_{\text {ff}} = \frac {8}{3}d_{\text {model}}.
Exception 2: In T5, they use d_{\text {ff}} = 64d_{\text {model}}. The logic for this was that we could maximize the MFU by increasing matrix size. Ended up going back to small d_{\text {model}}.

Rule 2: d_{\text {head}} = d_{\text {model}} / \text {num heads}
I believe the d_{\text {head}} is the output dim of each head.
This just says the total output dim for n heads is the same as if we did one head.
Means there is something important about splitting up the heads.

Rule 3: Aspect ratio = \frac {d_{\text {model}}}{n_{\text {layer}}} \approx 100-200
Pipeline dependent: if network speed is fast than parallelizing is easier and shallow networks are better.
If poor network speed then pipeline parallel might be more viable and deeper networks would be more parallelizable.

Rule 4: Vocab size
For single language models, vocab size is typically 30-50k
For multi language models, vocab size is typically 100-250k

Since there is so much data, it is not feasible to train your model for multiple epochs. This is actually nice in the sense that we do not have to worry about overfitting and performing regularization.

However, many of the large models are still trained with weight decay. Tatsu claims that this is not to do with regularization but actually due to some weird interaction with the learning rate schedule. I am not sure I entirely understood this part.

The softmax is ill-behaved due to the exponentials. In the transformer, we have two softmaxes: one at the end and one in the attention.
For the first, note \log \sigma (\mathbf {x})_i = \log (x_i) - \log \underbrace {\sum _{j=1}^{d} e^{x_j}}_{D(\mathbf {x})} The only problem is the denominator term. The idea is to enforce the D(\mathbf {x}) = 1 by regularizing via a penalty on \log D(\mathbf {x}) ie. \mathcal {L}_{\text {aux}} = 10^{-4} \log ^2(D(\mathbf {x})) With the \nabla D(\mathbf {x}) should be 0 and we are effectively only considering the non-exponential term.
For the attention, they primarily operate on the logits prior to the softmax. One way is via layer norm before the softmax. Another is via softcapping i.e. \mathrm {logits} = \mathrm {softcap} \cdot \tanh \left ( \frac {\mathrm {logits}}{\mathrm {softcap}} \right )
Notes on the paper Fast Transformer Decoding: One Write-Head is All You Need.

For,
b batch dimension,
n sequence length,
d hidden dimension,
h number of heads. The total FLOPS for attention are roughly bnd^2. This comes from
3nd^2 FLOPS to compute Q = XW_Q, K = XW_K, V = XW_V.
Need to do this b times for each input in batch. and the total memory accesses are roughly \underbrace {bnd}_{X} + \underbrace {bhn^2}_{\text {softmax}} + \underbrace {d^2}_{\text {projection}}. This gives high arithmetic intensity O\left (\left (\frac {h}{d} + \frac {1}{bn}\right )^{-1}\right )

However, if we do incremental inference then we must multiply our total number of memory accesses by n i.e. bn^2d + nd^2. This gives arithmetic intensity O\left (\left (\frac {n}{d} + \frac {1}{b}\right )^{-1}\right ), which requires large batch and short sequence length.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: I believe we just ignore the softmax memory contribution in the inference case because it does not scale with n anymore as we are computing the logits just for the next token. Therefore, it becomes a \frac {d}{h} term, which we can safely ignore?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The key is that the \frac {n}{d} term comes from the bn^2d term, where we are loading h (b \times n \times d / h) K and V matrices n times. Thus, we can improve the \frac {n}{d} term by a factor of h by simply not using a different K and V matrix for each head. This is the entire idea behind MQA.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Similar to the TJLA, we still can use h Q matrices because we do not need to load n of them into memory because only the last one matters for inference.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Group query attention is the same idea as MQA but instead of using one K and V for every head, they use a group of them. Where obviously the number of groups needs to be less than the number of heads.

html:figure.html:figcaption: Grouped query uses subset of K and V matrices.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Also inspired by this idea of reducing the dependence of K and V on the sequence length is sliding window attention.

The idea behind sliding window attention is to ensure the number of weight matrices needed for the keys K and values V does not scale with the sequence length. Intuitively, this means allowing each word to "attend" to only some fixed number of previous words rather than the whole sequence

html:figure.html:figcaption: "the" only sees "on" and "sat" rather than the full sentence.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (4/66)
We start by discussing a few essential questions one hopes to answer when they set out to train a large model.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: How long to train a 70b parameter model on 15T tokens on 1024 H100s?

Mysteriously, we spawn from the ether (will be explained later) that total_flops = 6 * 70e9 * 15e12. Intuitively, we know that we need to perform some computation for each parameter for each token. However, the 6 is still an ominous mystery. Given the total flops, we then can just take the GPUs FLOP/s multiply by the number of seconds in the day and divide total_flops by this number i.e. days = total_flops / flops_per_day

In practice, we must also consider the model flop utilization (MFU). Basically, our algorithm cannot utilize the entirety of the maximum FLOP/s provided by the hardware due to things like memory bandwidth, etc. To account for this in the calculation, they just take flops_per_day / 2.
What is the largest model that you can train on 8 H100s using AdamW?

An H100 has 80gb of shared memory i.e. h100_bytes = 80e9. The calculation then proceeds as # parameters, gradients, optimizer state bytest_per_param = 4 + 4 + (4 + 4) num_parameters = (h100_bytes * 8) / bytes_per_parameter what we need each of parameters, gradients, optimizer state will become clear later.
In practice, we also need to account for activations, which will depend on both batch size and sequence length.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Tensor Memory: Tensors are stored as a floating point number. Memory is determined by (i) number of values in tensor and (ii) data type of each value.

float16: here, we decrease both the fraction and exponent bits. Importantly, there are only 5 exponent bits making the effective range (2^{-6}, 2^{6}). The dynamic range for small numbers is pretty bad. This can cause small numbers to "die" effectively killing these neurons for the remainder of learning due to backpropagation.
bfloat16: to fix the problems with float16, they instead keep 8 exponent bits and reduce the fraction bits to 7. This maintains the same dynamic range as float32 while still only using 16 bits.

fp8: Two variants
E4M3: has 4 exponent bits and 3 mantissa bits
E5M2: has 5 exponent bits and 2 mantissa bits Requires modern Hopper Architecture i.e. H100 to perform operations. Also supported by TPUs.

html:ol.html:li: float32 training works but requires lots of memory
Using lower precision data types allows you to train larger models due to lower memory requirements, but can cause instability
To optimize this tradeoff, use mixed-precision training.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In pytorch, tensors are contiguous blocks of memory, where their shape is controlled by strides. A stride basically just refers to how far you have to jump in physical memory to correspond to incrementing the logical index i.e. in a (2, 3) matrix each row requires jumping 3 spots in physical memory. Thus, stride[1] = 3.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Calling .view((m, n)) just changes the stride but does not modify the physical memory. If you call .view that results in a non-contiguous view, then you cannot call .view again because it assumes contiguous indexing to properly adjust the strides. To deal with this, they have .contiguous() and .reshape() is basically .contiguous().view().
All elementwise operations make a copy i.e. x + y. A useful function for masked attention is triu().

Einops is a useful python library to keep track of high-dimensional matrix operations i.e. matmuls over batch_size, seqlen, etc. High level overview
Initialize like X[float.tensor, "batch seq hidden"] = torch.tensor((2, 3, 4))
Can perform matmul with named dims like z = einsum(x, y, "batch seq1 hidden, batch seq2 hidden -> batch seq1 seq2")
reduce: x = reduce(x, "x y z -> x y 1") is just like mean(x, axis=-1)
rearrange: x = rearrange(x, "... (heads hidden1) -> ... heads hidden 1")

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We refer to the total number of floating point operatings as FLOPS. Alternatively, we refer to the number of floating point operations per second as FLOP/s.
Given a promised FLOP/s, the model flop utilization is given by \frac {\text {actual FLOP/s}}{\text {promised FLOP/s}}

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Performing a matrix multiplication A \cdot B for A \in \mathbb {R}^{(B \times D)} and B \in \mathbb {R}^{(D \times K)}, requires 2 \times B \times D \times K FLOPS

fr:mainmatter.html:p: I hope to do a formal blog touring optimizers because I have written a paper on deep learning optimizers for my optimization course. Due to this, I will leave this blank for now. A brief list of the covered concepts are below:
A key formula to remember: \text {total memory} \approx 4 \times (\text {params} + \text {activations} + \text {grad size} + \text {optimizer state size})

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Another useful trick is to use low precision for forward pass activations, then use float32 for gradients and network parameters.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Trivially, we can do character-based tokenization i.e. mapping each character to a unique number. For example, \mathsf {chr}(97) = \text {``a''} and \mathsf {ord}(\text {``a''}) = 97. The compression ratio will be > 1 because each token corresponds to a character potentially consisting of more than one byte.

html:ol.html:li: Very large vocabulary
Many characters are quite rare.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: There is a fundamental tradeoff between compression ratio and vocabulary size. As an example, suppose we map every sequence of n bytes to a token. This would achieve a compression ratio of n. However, this would require 256^n tokens in our vocabulary.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Problem 2 was not entirely straight-forward to me. This actually reminds me of an idea from my information theory course, where we can assume we are given a "prior" over human language then we want to map low-probability characters to large strings in order to minimize the expected length (see huffman coding).

In byte-based tokenization, each byte is a token achieving a compression ratio of exactly 1, where a byte \mapsto [0, 256] . This is very elegant in the sense that our vocabulary size is fixed at 256.
fr:mainmatter.html:div: Problem: However, with this, the length of our encoding is # of bytes in the string, which will become too long.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In word-based tokenization, we simply split the string into the corresponding words then map each of these to a unique integer.
fr:mainmatter.html:div: Problem: The vocabulary size is "unbounded" i.e. if we see a word we have not seen before then we need to extend the vocabulary size.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the byte pair encoding (BPE), we instead train the tokenizer on raw text to automatically determine the vocabulary.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: In GPT2, they first split the raw text into words and then do this byte pair encoding.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (3/66)
This was a very short chapter just introducing the actual API for some very important system calls. Namely

The fork system call allows a program to duplicate itself in a new process from the current instruction. This is quite literally a duplication which entails giving the child its own
Address space
Registers
Program counter
Importantly, you identify whether you are in the child or the parent via the return value of rc (0 for child), (PID of child for parent).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Which process is run first (the parent or the child) is non-deterministic and depends on the CPU scheduling algorithm.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Due to the remark, we need some way to enforce ordering among parent and child. This is the motivation for the wait system call. Namely, when the parent calls wait() it tells the CPU not to schedule it until the child completes.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: From the previous section, we saw the data structure for a process included the state. I assume wait() is implemented by adjusting the process state in the PCB somehow?

Doing a bit more research, it seems this is on the right track. Additionally, when a child completes it enters the ZOMBIE state, where it stores all the relevant information of the process, so that the parent process can then use this information. How this is actually coordinated seems to involve signals and wait_entries that essentially track all the children of a parent. The OS can then get a signal of completion from a child and find the corresponding parent?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: While fork() is useful in the sense that it allows us to spawn new processes from a parent process, it is still limited in that it can only execute instructions following the line of the fork() call in the parent process.

They briefly mention signals: what I expect to be an important topic in the future. Namely, you can send a signall to a process via kill() and the recipient program can "catch" this signal via the system call signal().
This naturally leads to the introduction of a user. The user determines which processes they are allowed to signal, where the superuser can arbitrarily signal all processes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Deliberate-Practice (1/66)

A process consists of a few primary components
Memory: each process requires its own portion of memory for (i) to store the instructions of the program to execute and (ii) for the memory required by the calling program. This is referred to as the address space.
Registers: for those familiar with computers, instructions typically deal with registers, where information is loaded from memory into registers to perform computation. Additionally, there are special registers reserved for certain mechanisms i.e.
Program Counter (PC): This register is in charge of telling us what instruction we are currently on in the executing program.
Stack and Frame Pointer: Used to manage where we currently are on the stack.
In order to implement a process, one must support each of the following operations

html:li.html:p: The operating system must implement a mechanism to create a process. This consists of loading the program from disk, initializing memory (i.e. stack and heap), and jumping to main (typically).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The stack is allocated up front and does not change. However, typically a small amount of memory is allocated for the heap and it grows via malloc. This is non-trivial because if malloc is called without available heap memory then memory must be allocated by the OS. I need to look into how this is done more.
The OS will also initialize the parameters to main i.e. argc or argv.

html:ol.html:li: Destroy: Clearly, if a process is misbehaved or the user just does not want it to run any longer, there must be some mechanism to kill the process.
Wait: In the case of dependencies (piping?), it may be useful to wait for a process to complete.
Miscellaneous Control: The example provided in the book is to suspend a process.
Status: It is helpful to be able to get information about running processes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There are also process states. These states are running, ready, and blocked. These states are pretty self-explanatory.
It seems throughout the book we will be seeing implementation examples from the smaller xv6 OS.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: In addition to the process implementation below, there is also a data structure that must keep track of all the processes. This is the process list or process control block.
